MissionCommands.Message: Welcome to the subsystems activation lesson of the Lunar Module Academy.

This lesson will take you through the very basic understanding of the most important parts, so don't worry if you don't understand all of them. The next lessons will walk you through the systems at a deeper level.
Since the Lunar Module needs to be in an inactive state during the initial part of the mission, all of the major systems needs to be powered up before the LM is ready for flight.
We will be using the Checklist menu of the Mission Pad as a reference, and use the guidance logic to step through the major parts.
First of all, we are still in orbit around Earth. Check if the tunnel between the LM and the CM is open. If not open it, and enter the Lunar Module by using the View Selector menu.
If you take a glance at the panels, you can see that we have some power. Lights are illuminated and some caution and instrument lights are on.
This is because the Lunar Module batteries No. 1 and 4 are connected to the DC busses by using their low voltage taps.
Also, a lot of the instruments on Panel 1 and 2 have a light illuminated above them, indicating that they are not yet set up correctly.
As we walk through the steps in the checklist, we will see that the lights will extinguish.
I recommend using the flashlight while powering up the Lunar Module.
To get started, open the Mission Pad and click on the CHECKLISTS tab.
Switch the CHECKLISTS from Command Module to Lunar Module.
All the Subsystem Activation checklists can be found under the ACTIVATION section.
The goal is to walk through all of these, one by one, in the order from top to bottom.
Do not press anything yet, but skim through all of the checklist to get familiar with the major parts, and move on with the lesson when you are ready.
Ok, the first thing we need is to verify the circuit breakers, used to close the electrical circuit of all the systems inside the Lunar Module.
We have two panels with all available circuit breakers, namely Panels 11 and 16.
Panel 11 belongs to the Commander, and Panel 16 belongs to the Lunar Module Pilot.
The INITIAL SETUP is the first checklist, and begins with checking the circuit breakers on Panel 11. Some of these checklists has the RUN feature, and lets Reentry help you walk through the sections.

In this lesson you can either choose to use the checklist guide system, or perform the checklists manually. The INITIAL SETUP checklist consists of three main parts, one part for Panel 11, another for Panel 16, and lastly some final checks.
Complete the Panel 11 part of the INITIAL SETUP checklist now and press ROGER when done.
Panel 11 should now be set up and prepared for the rest of the activation checklists. Continue the checklist and complete the setup of Panel 16 as well. When Panel 16 is complete, press ROGER.
Now that the circuit breakers are in their correct position, we can move on to the next part. Step 3 asks you to power the LM from the CM umbilical.
This is something that needs to be done from the Command Module. Enter the command module, and set the LM power switch to the Up position.
The last thing we need to do in this section is opening the descent H2O valve. The ECS panel is behind the LMP station, so turn 180 degrees and look down to find it.
Good. The next part is the EPS activation, and will set up the electrical system. We will go through the details of the EPS in the EPS lesson.
You can do this manually, but if this is your the first time, I recommend using the checklist guide. I will explain some of the systems as you progress, so pay attention to these messages.
Start going through the EPS ACTIVATION & CHECKOUT now, while referencing the checklist. First of all, some of the circuit breakers are closed to power some instrumentation used to monitor the EPS.
The EPS ACTIVATION & CHECKOUT checklist will set up the initial electrical system and test that its major functions works, and finally setting up the AC power system.
When the EPS is set up, the 4 batteries in the descent stage are online, as well as AC power being converted by Inverter 2.
Next, set up the Primary Glycol Loop by following the PRIMARY GLYCOL LOOP ACTIVATION checklist. Start doing this now and press ROGER when you're done.
The Glycol is used to cool the equipment and systems in the Lunar Module, and will regulate their temperature.
Next is the CIRCUIT BREAKER checklist. In this checklist we'll connect all the major systems to the EPS. Start this section now, and press ROGER when done.
Next, set up the primary subliminator to get the glycol flowing through the systems. Do this now, and press ROGER when done.
The next section is to set up the Lighting. The Lunar Module has flood lights that provide general lighting to the cabin, as well as integral lights for the panels.

Please note that the flood lights are at maximum intensity while the hatch is open. Feel free to close the hatch while performing this task, using the C/Tools menu, and press the button next to the hatch, from the LM side.
Set up the lights now, and press ROGER when ready to continue.
Then there is the CAUTION & WARNING ARRAY CHECKOUT. This tests the caution and warning system, master alarm and the warning lights. Complete this now, and press ROGER when done.

Next we have the ECS activation and checkout checklist. Go ahead and use the RUN feature to complete this checklist. Optionally, if you need to save time, you can instead skip this and directly run the ECS BASIC (Unstaged) checklist to configure the ECS.
The next checklist is the COMMUNICATION systems. The communication systems are not yet developed, so you can skip this checklists.
I still recommend you to skim through these two parts before moving on.
The last few sections are used to test the ascent batteries, pressurize the RCS, and deploy the landing gear.
You should skim through the checklists to get familiar with each of the sections to be completed. Press ROGER when ready.
We have more batteries onboard, the Lunar battery and the ascent batteries. The Lunar Battery is used during the Lunar Stay, and as a backup.
The ascent batteries are mandatory for a normal ascent from the Lunar Surface back to the CM, powering the LM during ascent.
It is therefore important to check the batteries, and see if they are operational. Perform the ASCENT BATTERY ACTIVATION now, and press ROGER when ready.
The batteries are now in the normal operational configuration during the initial part of a LM mission, and during the descent stage.
Next, go through the Ascent and Descent Propulsion Systems (APS and DPS) sections.
These are all about checking the pressure and temperature of the substances for the ascent and descent stages. Press ROGER when these two sections are done.
We are now ready to pressurize the descent propulsion system. This is done using the explosives devices (ED) panel on Panel 8.

The ED panel will trigger controlled explosions to perform irreversible steps needed to operate the LM. In this case we will use a small helium tank named the ambient helium tank to initially pressurize the system.
You can verify this by checking that the AMB He has been reduced substantially after running the checklist. Run the checklist now, and press ROGER when ready.
The DPS system needs to be pressurized before being able to ignite the engine.
To control the LM, the Reaction Control System (RCS) is used. To be able to use the RCS, you first need to pressurize it, just like with the DPS.

The Explosive Devices system is once again used to do this. The ED has two redundant logical systems, as well as batteries (ED batteries). In this section, and in the landing gear section, both A and B will be tested individually.
Perform the RCS pressurization checklist now, and press ROGER when ready.
The next checklist is all about testing parts of the RCS, but can be skipped for now.

The final section is the deployment of the Landing Gear. The landing gear consists of four legs attached to the descent section. The legs are in a retracted position when in the SIVB and will need to be extended.
Once again, we will use the ED to do this. Run the checklist and press ROGER when ready.
Excellent job - that sure was a lot of systems! We barely scratched the surface in this lesson, where we focused on learning how to use checklists, and the procedures needed to activate the LM.
In the next lessons, we will dive deeper into these systems and learn how they are operated, and why you had to perform these steps.
That's it for now, I would recommend you to study these checklists. Some numbers might be off during development, as I yet have to stabilize these flows. Bye!

Title: Lesson 2 - Subsystem Activation
Description: In this lesson, you will learn how to activate the major systems of the Lunar Module, and walk through the checklist needed to set it all up.
BriefingText:
BRIEFING

Instructor: Patrick
Level: Advanced

In this lesson, will will take a glance at the subsystems activation checklist, and run the required parts to get the Lunar Module into an active state. There are many checklists use for the activation, and will touch almost every system the Lunar Module has to offer. 

This lesson will take you through the general understanding of the most important parts. The details will be covered in the next lessons, but it is highly recommended that you have read the Reentry Flight Manual for the Lunar Module to understand what the systems are doing in details.
